facts.text: Raja Profulla Nath Tagore died on July 2, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: One Raja Profulla Nath Tagore died on July 2, 1938, leaving an elaborate will dated March 14, 1927,

facts.text: Raja Profulla Nath Tagore left a will dated March 14, 1927.

anchor.surface_text: leaving an elaborate will dated March 14, 1927, by which certain legacies were left to specified persons

facts.text: Residue of estate given to five sons by clause 81 of the will.

anchor.surface_text: the residue being given to five sons. The residue was disposed of thus by clause 81 of the Will Save

facts.text: Legacies to be paid in full within 15 years of death per clause 10 of the will.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 of the said Will provided for the payment of the legacies thus The legacies fixed in this my present Will shall have to be paid in full within 15 years

facts.text: Probate of the will granted to the five sons on August 24, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Probate of the Will was granted to the said five sons on August 24, 1938, but by an order dated May 10,

anchor.surface_text: He claimed that the income was specifically receivable on behalf of the said five sons of the deceased, and their shares in the said income were definite

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected claim for 1950-51, assessed Administrator-General as executor since execution not complete.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the claim for the Assessment year 1950-51 on the ground that the Administrator-General of West Bengal is only an executor

facts.text: Similar order by Income-tax Officer for 1951-52.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

arguments.claim: High Court wrong; shares of five sons determinate at 1/5th each; variability of income does not make shares indeterminate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant in Civil Appeal 168 of 1964, Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, has urged that the High Court was wrong in holding that the shares of the five sons were indeterminate. He said that their shares were 1/5th each,

arguments.court_reasoning: Court accepts primary argument that s.41 inapplicable without reaching indeterminacy issue.

arguments.claim: Relied on Birendra Kumar Datta v. CIT to argue shares determinate despite income variability.

anchor.surface_text: and what has to be seen is whether the shares are determinate and not whether the actual sum, which each son would get is variable or not. Income may be variable but the shares of the sons are fixed. In this connection, he relied on the decision in Birendra Kumar Datta v. Commissioner of Income tax, Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: He further said that S. 41 was mandatory and if the proviso to S. 41 did not apply, the Income-tax Officer was bound to assess the appellant under S. 41.

arguments.court_reasoning: S.41 condition of receipt 'on behalf of' not satisfied; not mandatory in this case.

arguments.claim: S.41 does not apply as appellant did not receive income on behalf of five sons but as executor; executors not mentioned in s.41, assessable under ss.3,4.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, on behalf of the Revenue, submitted that S. 41 did not apply at all because in the facts and circumstances of the case, the appellant did not receive the income on behalf of the five sons but received it like an executor. He said that an executor was not mentioned in s. 41 and was assessable under ss. 3 4 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s number lead to the next step that an executor or administrator receives the income on behalf of the residuary legatee. In V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. C

arguments.court_reasoning: Explicitly inclined to accept this submission; s.41 inapplicable.

arguments.claim: In the alternative, shares of sons indeterminate.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, he argued that the share of the sons were indeterminate.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not reached as primary argument accepted.

arguments.claim: During administration, appellant receives income not on behalf of five sons but holds discretion for legacies/expenses; sons entitled only to residue.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the administration of the estate was not completed within the accounting periods in question. So the question boils down to this Did the appellant receive the income on his behalf or on behalf of the five sons during this period ? It seems to us that during the administration of the estate, the appellant did not receive the income on behalf of the five sons.

arguments.claim: English common law: residuary beneficiary not taxable on estate income during administration; no interest until residue ascertained.

anchor.surface_text: When he received the income, he had a discretion to use it either for paying legacy A or legacy B or for meeting the expenses... What the five sons were entitled to was the residue of the estate would be received by them finally, not as their income but as part of the residue. In England, apart from statutory provisions, a residuary beneficiary is not regarded as taxable on income of an estate in the course of administration.

arguments.claim: Following R. v. Income Tax Special Commissioners ex p Dr. Barnardos Homes: income during admin is executors', not residuary legatee's.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in R. v. Income Tax Special Commissioners 1   Ex parte, Dr. Barnardos Homes  supports the contention of the learned Attorney-General.

arguments.claim: S.41 inapplicable as Administrator-General receives income as legal representative, position same as executor.

anchor.surface_text: The position of an Administrator-General appointed de bonis non is in no way different from that of an executor vis-a-vis the income he receives from the estate. Accordingly, we hold that s. 41 of the Act is not applicable in the present case as the appellant received the income on his behalf and not on behalf of the five sons of the deceased Raja.

arguments.claim: High Court erred: express mention of Administrator-General in s.41 does not override condition of receiving on behalf of persons.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in this case had repelled the argument on behalf of the Revenue that the Administrator-General did not come within the purview of S. 41 of the Act on the ground that the Administrator-General when appointed by the Court is expressly covered by the section... In our opinion, the fact that the Administrator-General is expressly mentioned in S. 41 does not conclude the matter.

holdings.text: During the administration of the estate, the appellant did not receive the income on behalf of the five sons.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that during the administration of the estate, the appellant did not receive the income on behalf of the five sons. When he received the income, he had a discretion to use it either for paying legacy A or legacy B or for meeting the expenses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrator holds discretion for legacies and expenses; residuary beneficiaries entitled only to final residue, not income during administration, per common law principles.

holdings.text: The position of an Administrator-General appointed de bonis non is in no way different from that of an executor vis-a-vis the income he receives from the estate.

anchor.surface_text: The position of an Administrator-General appointed de bonis non is in no way different from that of an executor vis-a-vis the income he receives from the estate. Accordingly, we hold that s. 41 of the Act is not applicable in the present case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to executor status under Succession Act s.211; income received as legal representative during incomplete administration.

holdings.text: s. 41 of the Act is not applicable in the present case as the appellant received the income on his behalf and not on behalf of the five sons of the deceased Raja.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that s. 41 of the Act is not applicable in the present case as the appellant received the income on his behalf and not on behalf of the five sons of the deceased Raja.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Condition precedent for s.41 not satisfied: income not receivable 'on behalf of' beneficiaries during administration; assessable under ss.3 & 4.

holdings.text: The fact that the Administrator-General is expressly mentioned in S. 41 does not conclude the matter; the condition that the income must be received on behalf of a person or persons must be fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fact that the Administrator-General is expressly mentioned in S. 41 does not conclude the matter. The section prescribes another condition and that is that the income must be received by him on behalf of a -person or persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory condition of receipt 'on behalf of' overrides mere mention; High Court erred in holding otherwise.

holdings.text: The answers to the two questions set out in the beginning of the judgment must be in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above, the answers to the two questions set out in the beginning of the judgment must be in the affirmative. The appeals are, therefore, dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessments as individual (not representing beneficiaries) lawful under ss.3&4; maximum rate assessment legal.

precedents.citation: V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Following the principles laid down in the decisions in V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras 1  and Asit Kumar Ghose v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-Tax, West Bengal 1 , he held that the levy of tax on the separate individual incomes of the beneficiaries can be made only when the administration of the estate has been companyleted, and the residue of the estate has been ascertained.

precedents.case_name: V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: levy of tax on the separate individual incomes of the beneficiaries can be made only when the administration of the estate has been completed, and the residue of the estate has been ascertained

precedents.citation: Asit Kumar Ghose v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-Tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Following the principles laid down in the decisions in V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income Tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras 1  and Asit Kumar Ghose v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-Tax, West Bengal 1 , he held that the levy of tax on the separate individual incomes of the beneficiaries can be made only when the administration of the estate has been companyleted, and the residue of the estate has been ascertained.

precedents.case_name: Asit Kumar Ghose v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income-Tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: levy of tax on the separate individual incomes of the beneficiaries can be made only when the administration of the estate has been completed, and the residue of the estate has been ascertained

precedents.citation: Birendra Kumar Datta v. Commissioner of Income tax, Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: Income may be variable but the shares of the sons are fixed. In this companynection, he relied on the decision in Birendra Kumar Datta v. Commissioner of Income tax, Calcutta 1 . He further said that S. 41 was mandatory and if the proviso to S. 41 did number apply, the Income-tax Officer was bound to assess the appellant under S. 41.

precedents.case_name: Birendra Kumar Datta v. Commissioner of Income tax, Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: shares are determinate where proportions are fixed at 1/5th each even if actual sums are variable

precedents.citation: R. v. Income Tax Special Commissioners 1 Ex parte, Dr. Barnardos Homes 1 7 T.C. 646

anchor.surface_text: The decision in R. v. Income Tax Special Commissioners 1   Ex parte, Dr. Barnardos Homes  supports the companytention of the learned Attorney-General. The facts may be taken from the headnote. Mr. Denzil Thomson died on November 15, 1914, leaving the residue of his estate to Dr. Bamardos Homes National Incorporated Association.

precedents.case_name: R. v. Income Tax Special Commissioners, Ex parte, Dr. Barnardos Homes
precedents.cited_proposition: prior to the ascertainment of the residue, the residuary legatee had no interest in the testator's property, the taxed income of the estate prior to such ascertainment was income of the executors, and it was not received by them as trustees on behalf of the association
precedents.cited_holding: prior to the ascertainment of the residue, the Association as residuary legatee had no interest in the Testators property, that the taxed income of the estate prior to such ascertainment was income of the Executors, and that it was not received by them as trustees on behalf of the Association

anchor.surface_text: The House of Lords held, inter alia, following the decision, in Lord Sudeley v. Attorney-General 1 , that prior to the ascertainment of the residue, the Association as residuary legatee had nointerest in the Testators property, that the taxed income of the estate prior to such ascertainment was income of the Executors, and that it was number received by them as trustees on behalf of the Association.

precedents.cited_proposition: legatee of a share in a residue has no interest in any of the property of the testator until the residue has been ascertained
precedents.cited_holding: the legatee of a share in a residue has no interest in any of the property of the testator until the residue has been ascertained. His right is to have the estate properly administered and applied for his benefit when the administration is complete

precedents.citation: the Maria Celeste Samaritan Society of the London Hospital v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent cases such as the Maria Celeste Samaritan Society of the London Hospital v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1  and Corbett v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2  have taken the same view. In the latter case, the decision in Dr. Barnardos case was held to have laid down a general proposition applicable to all cases of residue which is being ascertained and which cannot be ascertained until the administration is companylete.

precedents.case_name: Maria Celeste Samaritan Society of the London Hospital v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: residuary legatee has no property in specific investments or income until administration complete; both corpus and income belong to executors during administration

precedents.citation: Corbett v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent cases such as the Maria Celeste Samaritan Society of the London Hospital v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1  and Corbett v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 2  have taken the same view. In the latter case, the decision in Dr. Barnardos case was held to have laid down a general proposition applicable to all cases of residue which is being ascertained and which cannot be ascertained until the administration is companylete.

precedents.case_name: Corbett v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Dr. Barnardo's case laid down general proposition applicable to all cases of residue being ascertained which cannot be until administration complete

precedents.citation: In re Cunliffe-Owen Mountain v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 3

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri relied on In re Cunliffe-Owen Mountain v. Inland Revenue Commissioners 3 , but, in our opinion, the Court of Appeal has number taken any different view. The Court of Appeal was companycerned with the interpretation of s. 27 1  of the Finance Act, 1949, whereby legacy duty was number payable in certain events.

precedents.case_name: In re Cunliffe-Owen; Mountain v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: title of residuary legatee remains the same before and after completion of administration

precedents.citation: V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax 4

anchor.surface_text: In V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax 4  the Madras High Court held that S. 41 of the Act had numberapplication where the administration of -the estate had number been companypleted by the executors.

precedents.case_name: V. M. Raghavalu Naidu v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: S. 41 of the Act had no application where the administration of the estate had not been completed by the executors

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that during the administration of the estate, the appellant did not receive the income on behalf of the five sons. When he received the income, he had a discretion to use it either for paying legacy A or legacy B or for meeting the expenses.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the fact that the Administrator-General is expressly mentioned in S. 41 does not conclude the matter. The section prescribes another condition and that is that the income must be received by him on behalf of a -person or persons.
